item.title: Holidays and Happiness - What makes a country happy?
item.description: Description Over the past year I have spent a good portion of time in the office studying and preparing for a career transition. Finding a suitable work-life balance has been difficult, especially with the clock ticking on my post-doctoral fellowship running out in December, 2017. Most free moments I have during the day are usually d towards studying something datascience related or doing some sports in an effort to keep mind and body balanced.

item.title: Predicting housing prices in Ames, Iowa - Captsone Project for Coursera Statistics with R Specialization
item.description: Description Part 1 - Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) Exploratory Data Analysis Part 2 - Development and assessment of an initial model, following a semi-guided process of analysis Section 2.1 An Initial Model Section 2.2 Model Selection Section 2.3 Initial Model Residuals Section 2.4 Initial Model RMSE Section 2.5 Overfitting Part 3 Development of a Final Model Section 3.1 Final Model Section 3.2 Transformation Section 3.3 Variable Interaction Section 3.

item.title: Curriculum Vitae
item.description: Dale Richardson, PhD I am a bioinformatics analyst of large scale genomics data and aspiring data scientist with an intense dedication to continued learning. Scientific research interests Post-transcriptional gene regulation, alternative splicing, comparative genomics, abiotic stress response Currently I conduct research on alternative splicing and abiotic stress responses in the model plant, Arabidopsis thaliana. In my spare time, I take online courses in preparation for a career transition into data analysis/data science.

item.title: About Dale
item.description: Currently I’m a postdoc in the Plant Molecular Biology Laboratory at the Instituto Gulbenkian de CiÃªncia (IGC), a research institution located just outside of Lisbon, Portugal. I primarily rely on R and a suite of bioinformatics tools to analyze large-scale genomic changes in response to abiotic stress in the model plant organism, Arabidopsis thaliana, commonly known as the “thale cress”. In transition Although I hold a special place in my heart for research science, it has become abundantly clear to me that I need to move into a new challenge.
